com.samysadi.acs.hardware.network.routingprotocol

Interface RoutingProtocol

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Cloneable, Entity, Notifier, Probed
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    RoutingProtocolDefault

    public interface RoutingProtocol
extends Entity
    A RoutingProtocol is used to select a Route between the parent device and another device.

    If calling NetworkDevice.isRoutingEnabled() on a given device returns false and if is not the parent device, then any of its interfaces can be included in a route generated by this RoutingProtocol.

    The route selection process is left to the implementation discretion. However, the selected route cannot contain a failed interface or an interface of which parent has failed.
    Furthermore, the route must be invalidated by throwing a NotificationCodes.RP_ROUTING_UPDATED notification whenever the route becomes invalid (for example, if an interface in the route fails, or a parent of an interface in the route fails).
    Implementations should not care about the route end-points (jobs and virtual machines) state. This is left for the NetworkOperation to care about.
    Doubtlessly, in order to achieve previous goals, implementations need to listen to these following notifications:

    • CoreNotificationCodes.FAILURE_STATE_CHANGED Check if the network device has failed. Or if any network interface of a network device has failed.
    • CoreNotificationCodes.POWER_STATE_CHANGED Check if the network device has been powered off.
    • CoreNotificationCodes.ENTITY_ADDED check if a new Network Interface is added.
    • CoreNotificationCodes.ENTITY_REMOVED check if an existing Network interface is removed.
    • NotificationCodes.NI_LINKING_UPDATED The Network Interface linking has changed.
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Samy Sadi , Belabbas Yagoubi

      • clone

        RoutingProtocol clone()
        Description copied from interface: Entity
        Creates a clone of this entity and sets its parent to null.

        This is a deep clone method which also clones children entities and sets their parents to the newly created clone.

        Implementations must ensure that the new clone will be independent from the current entity.

      • addRoutingHint

        void addRoutingHint(IpAddress destinationIpStart,
                  IpAddress destinationIpEnd,
                  NetworkInterface nextInterface)
        Adds a hint for the routing protocol.
        Implementations can perform faster routing when looking for a route to a device whose IP has already an associated routing hint. This may considerably reduce the simulation performance for big topologies.

        Implementations are not constrained to use this hint, nor they should rely on this hint to perform routing.
        In fact, an implementation may leak routing hints for some IP addresses, the hints may be deprecated after some devices fails, or it may receive requests to find routes for network devices that do not have an associated IpAddress.
        A best practice should be to try to find a route firstly using a hint if it is possible, and if not, use other methods to find a route. If a route has been found using a hint it is assumed optimal.

        Parameters:
        destinationIpStart - the first IP that is concerned by this hint. All IPs between this value and destinationIpEnd are also concerned by this hint.
        destinationIpEnd - the last IP that is concerned by this hint
        nextInterface - the next interface that will be used when looking for a route to an IP that matches the destinationIp and the destinationMask

      • clearRoutingHints

        void clearRoutingHints()
        Removes all routing hints that were previously added.

      • findRoute

        RoutingProtocol.RouteInfo findRoute(NetworkDevice destinationDevice,
                                  RoutingProtocol.RouteConstraints constraints)
        Returns a network route, to be used for network communications between the parent device and the given destinationDevice.

        If getParent() == destinationDevice then the returned RouteInfo will contain an empty route.

        If no route was found, null is returned.

        Parameters:
        destinationDevice - the destination device
        constraints - a RoutingProtocol.RouteConstraints that may be passed to exclude some devices from the route, or to add metric constraints for the returned route. Can be null.
        Returns:
        A RoutingProtocol.RouteInfo containing the selected route, an empty route or null
